DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Rite Aid Charges
DOC.TEXT: A judge has refused to dismiss charges that the president of Rite Aid Inc. tried to bribe an Ohio State Pharmacy Board member. Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Lillian J. Greene on Wednesday set a tentative trial date of Jan. 15 for Martin L. Grass, who heads the nation's largest drug store chain. Grass, 35, and his attorneys appeared in court Friday to ask Greene to drop the charges. Grass has denied government charges that he and Rite Aid, which is based in Shiremanstown, Pa., were trying to put people on the pharmacy board who were sympathetic to the company's interests. A secret Cuyahoga County grand jury unsealed on Aug. 1 accused Grass and Rite Aid of offering a $33,000 bribe to pharmacy board member Melvin Wilczynski. Prosecutors said the money was to be in exchange for Wilczynski's stepping down from the board. Rite Aid has said it paid Wilczynski $33,249 for a legal buyout of his consulting contract with Lane Drug Co., a division of Peoples Drug Stores Inc. Rite Aid acquired Peoples Drug in April. The indictment charges Grass and Rite Aid with bribery and possession of criminal tools. It alleges that Grass and the company used an aircraft as the criminal tool last March and April. Both charges are felonies. The maximum penalty for the bribery charge is a 10-year prison term and a $5,000 fine, and the charge of possession of criminal tools is punishable by a maximum of five years in prison and a $2,500 fine. Rite Aid has 29,000 employees and more than 2,200 discount drug stores across the nation.
